poem:
**The Empty Wardrobes of Autumn**

Mild October and hesitant skies,  
consumers pacing in uncertain aisles,  
Primark, normally a cacophony of choice,  
now whispers quiet amidst dwindling warmth.  
Shirts hang like untold stories,  
waiting for weather or a whim—  
amidst fabric and fall,  
a season pauses, breaths held,  
draped in layers of lighter grief.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Primark sales in first post-Covid fall amid mild weather and low consumer confidence Sales at Primark have fallen for the first time since the pandemic forced all shops in the UK to close, as mild weather and low consumer confidence hit sales. Associated British Foods (ABF), which owns the fashion retailer, said sales at Primark’s established stores fell 6% in the final three months of the year. “Trading activity within elements of our shopper base". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
